document_title: Acute pancreatitis: causes, symptoms, complications and diagnosis
subsection_content:
When digestive enzymes are activated while still in the pancreas, they stimulate the cells of the pancreas and cause inflammation. If acute pancreatitis is repeated, it will cause damage to the pancreas and lead to chronic pancreatitis.(3)
Scar tissue can form in the pancreas, causing loss of function. A poorly functioning pancreas can cause digestive problems and diabetes.
Risk factors for acute pancreatitis include:
Gallstones Alcohol Certain medications Lipidemia (hypertriglyceridemia) High blood calcium levels (hypercalcemia), possibly due to overactive parathyroid glands (hyperparathyroidism) Pancreatic cancer Surgery abdomen Cystic fibrosis Abdominal lesions Obesity Diabetes Family history of pancreatitis Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), a procedure used to treat gallstones, can also lead to pancreatitis. Congenital defects (annular pancreas) Genetic disorders (hereditary pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis, alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency) Hypercalcemia Parasitic infections (Ascaris lumbricoides, Cryptosporidium, Clonorchis sinensis, Microsporidia) Kidney disease ( hemodialysis) Toxins (scorpion bites, organophosphate poisoning) Vasculitis (Polynodularitis, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus) Autoimmune pancreatitis, type I (systemic IgG4-related disease) and type II Viral infections (Coxsackie, Cytomegalovirus, Echovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, Hepatitis A/B/C, HIV, Mumps, Rubella, Varicella) Bacterial infections (Campylobacter jejuni, Legionella, Leptospirosis, Mycobacterium avium, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycoplasma) ; Gallstones; Alcohol; Taking certain medications; Lipid disease (hypertriglyceridemia); High blood calcium levels (hypercalcemia), possibly due to overactive parathyroid glands (hyperparathyroidism); Pancreatic cancer; Abdominal surgery; Cystic fibrosis; Abdominal damage; Fat; Diabetes; Family history of pancreatitis; Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), a procedure used to treat gallstones, can also lead to pancreatitis.; Congenital malformations (annular pancreas); Genetic disorders (hereditary pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis, alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency); Hypercalcemia; Parasitic infections (Ascaris lumbricoides, Cryptosporidium, Clonorchis sinensis, Microsporidia); Kidney disease (hemodialysis); Toxins (scorpion bites, organophosphate poisoning); Vasculitis (Polynodularitis, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus); Autoimmune pancreatitis, type I (systemic IgG4-related disease) and type II; Viral infections (Coxsackie, Cytomegalovirus, Echovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, Hepatitis A/B/C, HIV, Mumps, Rubella, Varicella); Bacterial infections (Campylobacter jejuni, Legionella, Leptospirosis, Mycobacterium avium, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycoplasma)
Sometimes, pancreatitis has no known cause, called idiopathic pancreatitis
